en: Thousands of visitors to the historic city of Stone Town, Zanzibar, have followed the sound of music to the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that promotes and preserves the islands’ musical traditions of the Swahili Coast along the Indian Ocean.
yor: Ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àlejò tí ó ń rọ́ wìtìwìtì wá sí ìlú Stone Town, Zanzibar tí ó kún fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá, ti tẹ̀lé ìró orin Iléèwé Orin kíkọ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-èdèe Dhow (DCMA), ilé ẹ̀kọ́ orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àwọn àṣà orin erékùṣù náà tí ó sún mọ́ Swahili ní ẹ̀báa Omi Òkun India.
mt0: <pad> Òkú àwọn ìrìnnà sí ilé ìjọba àtijọ́ ti Stone Town, Zanzibar, ti tẹ̀lé ìgbésí orin si Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that promotes and preserves the island’s musical traditions of the Swahili Coast along the Indian Ocean.</s>

en: Since 2002, the school has promoted and preserved the Zanzibar's unique mix of Arab, Indian and African cultures through music.
yor: Láti ọdún-un 2002, ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà ti ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àkójọpọ̀ orin Lárúbáwá, India àti Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí kò lẹ́lẹ́gbẹ́.
mt0: <pad> Since 2002, the school has promoted and preserved the unique mix of Arab, Indian and African cultures through music.</s>

en: After 17 years, the school faces a financial crisis that threatens its closure.
yor: Lẹ́yìn-in ọdún kẹtàdínlógún, iléèwé náà kò rí owó tí ó tówó nínú àpò ìkówó sí tí ó sì leè fa kí iléèwé náà ó di títì pa.
mt0: <pad> lẹ́yìn ọdún 17, ilé ìwé náà ni ìṣòro ọrọ̀ ajé tó lè jẹ́ kí ó kúrò.</s>

en: Nearly 70% of its 80 full-time students can't afford to pay their tuition, which comes to about $13 USD per month, according to an official DCMA press release.
yor: Nínú ìwé ìgbéròyìnjáde tí àwọn aláṣẹ DCMA tẹ̀ jáde, ìdá àádọ́rin nínú àwọn ọgọ́rin akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni kò rí owó iléèwé wọn tí ó tó bíi $13 USD lóṣù san.
mt0: <pad> 70% of its 80 full-time students can't afford to pay their tuition, which comes to about $13 USD per month, according to the DCMA press release.</s>

en: While the school has received support over the years from international donors and diplomatic missions, they face a gap in funding that may force them to shut their doors at the historic Old Customs House.
yor: Pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn àwọn onínúure tí ó ti dáwó fún iléèwé náà, owó tí ó kù ní sísan ṣì pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó fi jẹ́ wípé, ó ṣe é ṣe kí ilẹ̀kùn-un iléèwé náà tí ó wà nínú Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́.
mt0: <pad> While the school has received support over the years from international donors and diplomatic missions, they face a gap in funding that may force them to shut their doors at the historic Old Customs House.</s>

en: Without crucial funds to continue, DCMA students and staff fear that the soulful sounds that flow through the hallways of this iconic institution that make these islands sing — may cease.
yor: Láìsí owó tí ó tówó nílẹ̀ láti tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA àti òṣìṣẹ́ ń fòyà kí ìró amọ́kànbalẹ̀ tí ó ń sun jáde láti inúu gbọ̀ngán olókìkí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí tí ó mú erékùṣù yìí kọrin — leè wọ òkùnkùn.
mt0: <pad> Without crucial fund to continue, DCMA students and staff fear that the soulful sounds that flow through the hallways of this iconic institution that make these islands sing — may cease.</s>

en: The school not only teaches and promotes traditional culture and heritage through music, but it's also home to a community of young musicians who seek alternatives to making a living as creatives.
yor: Orin àti ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti àjogúnbá nìkan kọ́ ni ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà fi gbajúmọ̀, àmọ́ ó jẹ́ ilé fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ń wà ibi tí wọn yóò ti fi ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀.
mt0: <pad> Ìdílé náà kò ní ìkọ́ àti ìgbésí àṣà àti ìtàn àti ìlú àti ìtàgé nípasè orin, ṣùgbọ́n ó jẹ́ ilé ìdílé àwọn ọdọ̀ akọrin àti ìtọ́jú àti ìyìn àti ìsìn àti ìwádìí àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti ìsìn àti

en: A DCMA student learns the qanun, a featured instrument in classical taarab songs. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
yor: Akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA kan ń kọ́ qanun, ohun èlò orin ayédáadé orin taarab. Àwòrán láti iléèwé DCMA.
mt0: <pad> A DCMA student learns the qanun, a featured instrument in classical taarab songs. Photo courtesy of the DCMA</s>

en: "We [have started] to face a very challenging financial moment", said Alessia Lombardo, managing director of the DCMA, in an official DCMA video.
yor: "A [ti bẹ̀rẹ̀] sí í ní rí ìdojúkọ ìgbà tí ó nira", alákòóso àgbàa DCMA, Alessia Lombardo sọ, nínúu àwòrán fídíò DCMA kan.
mt0: <pad> "A [bẹrẹ] lati duro ni akoko ti o ṣoro pupọ ni owo," sọ pé Alessia Lombardo, oludari agba ti DCMA, ninu fidio ofin DCMA.</s>

en: "From now to the next six months, we are not sure that we can guarantee the salaries to our teachers and staff".
yor: Láti ìsinsìnyí lọ títí di oṣù mẹ́fà sí àsìkò yìí, a kò rí àrídájú tí ó rinlẹ̀ wípé a ó leè san owó oṣù àwọn olùkọ́ni àti òṣìṣẹ́ẹ".
mt0: <pad> "From now to the next six months, we are not sure that we can guarantee the salaries to our teachers and staff."</s>

en: At the moment, 19 master teachers and small core staff have gone without salaries for over three months as the school struggles to secure strong funding partnerships and explore sustainable funding models for a school.
yor: Ní àkókò tí a wà yìí, àwọn àkàwé-gboyè olùkọ́ 19 àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ mìíràn ti ṣiṣẹ́ fún oṣù mẹ́ta gbáko láì gba owó lọ sílé nítorí àìsí owó nínúu kóló iléèwé.
mt0: <pad> Akoko yii, 19 awọn olukọni akọkọ ati awọn oṣiṣẹ ipilẹ kekere ti wa ni awọn oṣu mẹta laisi awọn owó nigba ti ile-iwe naa n gbiyanju lati gba awọn alabaṣepọ awọn ohun elo ati lati ṣe awọn awoṣe awọn ohun elo awọn ile-iwe.</s>

en: While the archipelago is known as a tourist destination for its pristine beaches and luxury hotels, the majority of local people struggle with high unemployment even as poverty has slightly decreased, according to The World Bank.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Ilé Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ṣe ti ṣàlàyé wípé, pẹ̀lú bí a ti ṣe mọ agbègbè tí iléèwé náà wà fún ibi ìrìn-àjò ìgbafẹ́ nítorí àwọn etíkun àtijọ́ àti ilé ìtura olówó ńláńlá tí ó kángun síbẹ̀, ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ló ń bá àìníṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ pò ó pàápàá bí ìṣẹ́ ṣe ti gbé fúkẹ́ ju ti ìgbà kan lọ.
mt0: <pad> While the archipelago is known as a tourist destination for its pristine beaches and luxury hotels, the majority of local people struggle with high unemployment even as poverty has slightly decreased, according to The World Bank.</s>

en: For 17 years, the DCMA has worked tirelessly to promote and protect Zanzibar’s rich heritage and traditions through music.
yor: Fún ọdún mẹ́tàdínlógún, DCMA ti ṣiṣẹ́ àṣekúdórógbó nípa lílo orin ṣe ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpamọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ àjogúnbá àti àṣà Zanzibar.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ́.</s>

en: The birthplace of legendary taarab singers Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, or Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is home to musical genres that emerged through cultural exchange and collaboration along the Swahili Coast for hundreds of years.
yor: Orírun àwọn olóhùn-iyò akọrin taarab, Siti Binti Saad àti Fatuma Binti Baraka, tí a tún mọ̀ sí Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar ni ilé èyí-ò-jọ̀yìí orin tí ó ti inúu ìbàṣepapọ̀ àṣà àti àjọṣe ọlọ́dún gbọgbọrọ tí ó wà láàárín àwọn àdúgbò ẹ̀ka Swahili.
mt0: <pad> Zanzibar, the birthplace of legendary taarab singers Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, or Bi. Kidude, is home to musical genres that emerged through cultural exchange and collaboration along the Swahili Coast for hundreds of years.</s>

en: Today, students can learn traditional musical genres like taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, along with instruments like drums, qanun and oud, as gatekeepers — and interpreters — of culture and tradition.
yor: Láyé òde òní, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ leè kọ́ orin ìbílẹ̀ bíi taarab, ngoma àti kidumbak, pẹ̀lú àfikún àwọn ohun èlò ìkọrin bíi ìlù ní oníranànran, qanun àti oud, gẹ́gẹ́ bí alápamọ́ — àti òǹgbifọ̀ — àṣà àti ìṣe.
mt0: <pad> Awọn ọmọde le kọ awọn orin akọkọ bi taarab, ngoma ati kidumbak, pẹlu awọn ohun ẹrọ bii drums, qanun ati oud, bii ẹni ti o jẹ oluṣọgba - ati oniṣere - ti aṣa ati aṣa.</s>

en: Neema Surri, a violin player at the DCMA, has been studying the violin since the age of 9.
yor: Neema Surri, a ta violin ní DCMA, ti ń kọ́ bí a ti ṣe ń ta ohun èlòo violin láti ọmọdún mẹ́sàn-án mẹ́nu lé ọ̀rọ̀ nínú àwòrán fídíò DCMA náà.
mt0: <pad> Neema Surri, a violin player at the DCMA, has been studying the violin since the age of nine.</s>

en: "I know many young people who would like to study music but they can’t afford the minimal tuition fee because they are poor and unemployed", Surri said in the DCMA video.
yor: "Mo mọ àwọn ọ̀dọ́mọdé tí ó máa nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí kíkọ́ orin ṣùgbọ́n wọn kò leè san owó ìmẹ̀kọ tí ó jẹ́ owó iléèwé nítorí wípé wọn kúṣẹ̀ẹ́ wọn kò sì ní iṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ".
mt0: <pad> "Mo mọ ọpọlọpọ awọn ọdọmọkunrin ti o fẹ lati ka orin ṣugbọn wọn ko le gba owo ìwé àkọsílè nítorí wọn jẹ́ awọn ọdọmọkunrin àti àwọn alaṣẹ́ ìṣòro", Surri said in the DCMA video.</s>

en: Students at the DCMA rehearse at the Old Customs House, where the school is based, in Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.
yor: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA ń fi ohun èlò ìkọrin olókùn tín-ín-rín kọrin nínú Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́, níbití iiléèwé náà fi ìkàlẹ̀ sí, ní Stone Town, Zanzibar, lọ́dún-un 2019. Àwòrán jẹ́ ti iléèwée DCMA.
mt0: <pad> Ñàì íà òîì ñâåñòè íà áîëüøåé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà òîðûé ìàññà íà

en: After completing DCMA workshops, certificate and diploma courses, many DCMA students go on to perform on world stages as award-winning bands and solo artists.
yor: Ní ìparí àwọn ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA, tí wọ́n ti gba ìwé ẹ̀rí àti ní òpin ẹ̀kọ́ ọlọ́dún kan, púpọ̀ nínú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA ni ó ti di àgbà ọ̀jẹ́ tí wọ́n sì í ṣeré lórí ìtàgé kárí ayé.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ ọ?</s>

en: Zanzibar’s Amina Omar Juma, a former DCMA student and current DCMA teacher, recently returned from a tour in South Africa with her critically acclaimed, "Siti and the Band", known for "fusing the roots" by blending traditional taarab sounds with contemporary, layered rhythms.
yor: Ọmọ bíbíi Zanzibar, tí ó jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA nígbà kan rí, tí ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ni ní iléèwé kan náà báyìí, Amina Omar Juma tòun ti ìlú mọ̀ọ́ká ẹgbẹ́ akọrin rẹ̀, tí ó ń "fi àṣà ìró orin ìbílẹ̀ " taarab papọ̀ mọ́ ti ìgbàlódélonígbàńlò kọrin, ìyẹn "Siti àti Ẹgbẹ́ ", ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ padà wọ̀lú láti ìrìnàjò orin kíkọ kan ní orílẹ̀-èdèe South Africa.
mt0: <pad> Amina Omar Juma, a former DCMA student and current DCMA teacher, recently returned from a tour in South Africa with her critically acclaimed, "Siti and the Band", known for "fusing the roots" by blending traditional taarab sounds with contemporary, layered rhythms.</s>

en: She and other band members, also former DCMA students, released their first full album, "Fusing the Roots", in 2018, going on to perform at Sauti za Busara, East Africa's largest music festival, that same year.
yor: Òun, àwọn díẹ̀ nínú ẹgbẹ́ akọrin rẹ̀ àti àpapọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA ní ìgbà kan rí ṣe àgbéjáde àwo orin wọn àkọ́kọ́, "Fusing the Roots", ní ọdún-un 2018, tí ó mú wọn oi ng o òǹwòran lára yá ní Sauti za Busara, tí í ṣe àjọ̀dún orin kíkọ tí ó gbàràdá jù lọ ní Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> O ati awọn ọmọ ile-iwe DCMA miiran, awọn ọmọ ile-iwe DCMA, ti ṣe akọkọ aworan wọn, "Fusing the Roots", ni 2018, lọ siwaju lati ṣiṣẹ ni Sauti za Busara, East Africa's biggest music festival, ni ọdun kanna.</s>

en: Here's Siti and the Band's "Nielewe" ("Understand Me") and music video, depicting scenes from Zanzibar while telling the story of a woman who experiences domestic abuse and dreams of life in music, much like Omar Juma's personal story:
yor: Híhàyín ni orin Siti àti Ẹgbẹ́ “Nielewe” (“Gbó mi yéké”) àti àwòrán orin náà, tí ó ṣe àfihàn-an àwòrán-an, tí ó sọ ìtàn obìnrin kan tí ó ń rí ìdojúkọ abẹ̀-ilé, tí ó sì ń dárò ara rẹ̀. Ìtàn náà jọ ti Omar Juma fúnra rẹ̀:
mt0: <pad> Eyi ni Siti and the Band's "Nielewe" ("Understand Me") ati music video, depicting scenes from Zanzibar while telling the story of a woman who experiences domestic abuse and dreams of life in music, much like Omar Juma's personal story.</s>

en: Read more: East African women in the music industry sing out against male domination
yor: Kà síwájú sí i: Àwọn akọrin lóbìnrin Ìlà-Oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ kọrin tako àìfààyè gba obìnrin àwọn ọkùnrin.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ?</s>

en: A history of cultural crossroads and collaboration
yor: Ìtàn nípa àyálò àṣà àti àjọṣepọ̀
mt0: <pad> A history of cultural crossroads and a lack of knowledge</s>

en: Over 15,000 visitors have passed through the academy’s iconic building to enjoy live performances, workshops and classes and interact with passionate DCMA musicians who represent the future of Zanzibar culture and heritage, according to the DCMA.
yor: Ó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dógún àlejò ni ó ti wo eré, gba ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti bá àwọn akọrin lóríṣiírísí ọjọ́ ọ̀la ní iléèwé olókìkí náà ní gbólóhùn rí.
mt0: <pad> 15,000 visitors have passed through the academy’s iconic building to enjoy live performances, workshops and classes and interact with passionate DCMA musicians who represent the future of Zanzibar culture and heritage, according to the DCMA.</s>

en: Drawing from a complex history of Indian, Arab and African exchange, the school celebrates the influence of "dhow countries", with inspiration from cultures that converged along the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.
yor: Iléèwé náà ti ṣe àyálò àti àmúpapọ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àṣà "àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè dhow", tí ó wà ní ìtòsíi Òkun India àti Ọ̀gbùn-un Persia.
mt0: <pad> Ìdílé náà ní ìtàn ìgbésẹ̀ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ti India, Arab àti Afirika, ìwé náà sì yí ìfẹ́ àwọn ilẹ̀ "dhow" wọ́n sì gbà ìmọ̀lẹ̀ láti àwọn àṣà tí ó kópa lórí òkun Indian àti Gulf Persian.</s>

en: The Omani Sultanate, a "major maritime force from the 17th to 19th centuries", shifted its seat of power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.
yor: Agbègbèe Omani Sultanate, tí ó jẹ́ " ibi gbòógì àwọn alágbára atukọ̀ orí omi ní ọgọ́rùn-ún Ọdún-un kẹtàdínlógún sí kọkàndínlógún sẹ́yìn", gbé àga agbára rẹ̀ láti Muscat sí Zanzibar ní ọdún-un 1840.
mt0: <pad> Omani Sultanate, a "major maritime force from the 17th to 19th centuries", moved its seat of power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.</s>

en: From Stone Town, Omani kings oversaw elaborate systems of maritime trade, including cloves, gold, and textiles, powered by strong winds that set dhows — traditional Arab vessels — sailing across the Indian Ocean, from India to Oman to East Africa.
yor: Láti Stone Town, àwọn ọba Omani ń tukọ̀ọ okòwò orí omi ìgbà náà tí ó fẹjú, títí kan kànáfùrù, wúrà, àti aṣọ , látàrí àwọn ìjì líle tí ń tu àwọn ọkọ̀ ìbílẹ̀ẹ Lárúbáwáa — dhows — ní oríi Òkun Indian, láti India sí Oman títí lọ dé Ìlà-Oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> From Stone Town, Omani kings oversaw elaborate systems of maritime trade, including cloves, gold, and textiles, powered by strong winds that set dhows — traditional Arab vessels — sailing across the Indian Ocean, from India to Oman to East Africa.</s>

en: Young Zanzibaris recognize the importance of connecting with the past to determine their future and the music created today expresses that desire to bridge the old with the new.
yor: Àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ní Zanzibar mọ rírìi ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá tí ó ní ohun ńlá ní í ṣe fún ọjọ́ ọ̀la wọn, ni wọ́n fi ń ṣe àdàlù èyí tí a rí nínú àwọn orin òde òní tí wọn ń gbé jáde.
mt0: <pad> Zanzibaris ọdọmọkunrin ti o mọ awọn pataki ti o ni lati sopọ pẹlu awọn igba atijọ lati pinnu awọn ọjọ iwaju wọn ati orin ti a ṣẹda loni fihan pe o fẹ lati sopọ awọn aṣa atijọ pẹlu awọn tuntun.</s>

en: DCMA students and teachers recently formed "TaraJazz", a blend of traditional taarab and modern jazz.
yor: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti olùkọ́ni DCMA ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ẹ "TaraJazz" láì pẹ́ yìí, èyí tí ó jẹ́ àdàlù orin ìbílẹ̀ taarab àti orin Jazz òde òní.
mt0: <pad> Ẹgbẹ́ àwọn akẹ́ẹ̀kọ́ DCMA ṣẹ́ṣẹ́ dá "TaraJazz", ìgbésí àṣà taarab àti jazz àtijọ́.</s>

en: Their violinist, Felician Mussa, 20, has only been studying the violin for 3.5 years; TaraJazz is one of the most sought-after bands on the islands, captured here by photographer Aline Coquelle:
yor: Ata violin, Felician Mussa, ọmọ ogún ọdún, ti ń kọ́ ohun èlò ìkọrin olókùn tín-ín-rín náà fún ọdún mẹ́ta àtààbọ̀; TaraJazz jẹ́ ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ẹgbẹ́ akọrin tí ó àwọn ènìyàn máa ń pè sí òde jù lọ ní àwọn erékùṣù náà, ni ó wà nínú àwòrán tí ayàwòrán tí Aline Coquelle yà:
mt0: <pad> Ìyàwọn ìgbìmọ̀ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìkẹ́kọ

en: The Swahili coast tells the story of epic cultural exchanges and the DCMA continues this tradition through its musical collaborations.
yor: Agbègbèe Swahili sọ ìtàn pàṣípààrọ àṣà ìbílẹ̀ tí DCMA ṣì ń tẹ̀síwájú nínúu rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ àwọn orin-in rẹ̀ .
mt0: <pad> Òkè Swahili sọ̀rọ̀ ìtàn àwọn ìgbésí ìṣọ́ àtijọ́ àti DCMA tẹ̀síwájú àwọn ìṣọ́ àtijọ́ nípasè àwọn ìṣẹ́gun orin.</s>

en: Every year, the school hosts an initiative called "Swahili Encounters", matching well-known musicians hailing from Africa, the Middle East, Europe and North America with DCMA students to create original musical compositions within a week-long period.
yor: Lọ́dọọdún, iléèwé náà máa ń gbàlejò fún ètò tí a pè ní "Ìkọlù Swahili", tí ó mú àgbárijọpọ̀ọ àgbà akọrin láti Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, Ìlú Abẹ́-àkóso Lárúbáwá, Ilẹ̀ Éróòpù àti Àríwá Amẹ́ríkà pẹ̀lú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA láti ṣe orin láàárín ọ̀sẹ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀</s>

en: At the end of the "encounter", the newly-formed collaboration performs at Sauti za Busara, and many of these collaborations turn into life-time friendships that transcend the boundaries of language and culture, proving music is a universal language.
yor: Ní ìgbẹ̀yìngbẹ́yín "ìkọlù" náà, àgbárijọpọ̀ tuntun náà yóò ta bí elégbé ní Sauti za Busara, tí àjọṣepọ̀ wọ̀nyí yóò sì di ìbáṣepọ̀ ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí kò mọ ìyàtọ̀ èdè àti àṣà, tí ó fi hàn gbangba wálíà wípé èdè kan náà tí gbogbo ayé gbọ́ ni orin.
mt0: <pad> Àti ìgbà tí wọ́n bá mọ̀, ìjọba ti o ti ṣẹ́lẹ̀ nínú ìfẹ́ yí ṣe ìrìnnà lórí èdè àti àṣà, àti ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìjọba yìí jẹ́ ìbáṣepọ̀ ìgbàlódé tó kọjá àwọn ìlànà èdè àti àṣà, ìrírí pé orin jẹ́ èdè gbogbo.</s>

en: DCMA offers weekly live performances showcasing students’ talents and collaborations with visiting musicians, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of DCMA.
yor: DCMA máa ń ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ètò orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ ẹ̀bùn orin kíkọ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti àfihàn àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀kọrin àlejò hàn ní, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA ni ó ni àwòrán.
mt0: <pad> DCMA offers weekly live performances showcasing students’ talents and collaborations with visiting musicians, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019.</s>

en: The DCMA recognizes that music empowers and unites people across cultures — and it also employs talented youth living in a struggling economy with limited job opportunities.
yor: DCMA mọ rírì orin gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó leè ró àwọn ènìyàn lágbára àti gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó lè mú ìṣọ̀kan àti ìrẹ́pọ̀ bá àwọn ènìyàn láì wo ti àṣà — ó sì tún ń pèsè àǹfààní iṣẹ́ fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ní ẹ̀bùn àmọ́ tí ó ń tiraka láti jẹ.
mt0: <pad> DCMA mọ̀ pé orin n ṣe ìgbésí àti ìjọba àwọn ènìyàn kọjá àṣà — o si n ṣiṣẹ́ àwọn ọdọmọdé tó ni ẹ̀tọ́ nínú ọrọ-ọrọ̀ ìṣòro pẹ̀lú awọn ìfẹ̀ sílẹ̀.</s>

en: For the 1,800 students who have trained at the DCMA, this is the only musical home they know, where they can learn and grow as professional musicians and artists.
yor: Fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ 1,800 tí ó ti gba ìdánilẹ́kọọ́ ní DCMA, èyí nìkan ni ibi ilé orin tí wọ́n mọ̀, níbi tí wọ́n ti ń kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ tí wọ́n sì ti ń ní àlékún ìmọ̀ nípa iṣẹ́ orin kíkọ àti bí a ṣe ń di òǹkọrin.
mt0: <pad> Ìdílé ìgbàlódé fún àwọn ọmọ-ẹ̀yìn 1,800 tí wọ́n ti kọ́ ní DCMA, ìdílé ìgbàlódé kan ni wọ́n mọ̀, níbi tí wọ́n le kọ́ àti gbé bí àwọn olùṣèrè àti àwọn akọrin.</s>

en: One traveler from Spain, who recently visited the DCMA, wrote on TripAdvisor: "Personally, meeting the musicians was the best piece of my time on this island".
yor: Arìnrìn-àjò kan láti Spain, tó bẹ DCMA wò ní kò pẹ́ yìí, kọ sí oríi TripAdvisor: "Ní tèmi, ìṣalábàápàdée àwọn akọrin ni ìgbà tí ó meet jù lọ fún mi ní erékùṣù yìí".
mt0: <pad> Òkùnrin kan láti Spain, ti o ti lọ sí DCMA, kọ́ lórí TripAdvisor: "Lara mi, ìbò àwọn akọrin ni apá ìgbà tí mo ní ìrírí ní ìlú yìí.</s>

en: As Zanzibar’s tourism sector rapidly grows, the DCMA believes that music plays an essential role in the celebration, preservation and promotion of Swahili culture, heritage and history.
yor: Bí ẹ̀ka ìrìn-àjò afẹ́ẹ Zanzibar ṣe ń gbèrò sí i, DCMA nígbàgbọ́ wípé orin ní ipa kan gbòógì ní í ṣe nínú àjọyọ̀, ìpamọ́ àti ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpolongo àṣà, àjogúnbá àti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwáa Swahili.
mt0: <pad> Zanzibar's tourist sector is rapidly growing, the DCMA believes that music plays an essential role in the celebration, preservation and promotion of Swahili culture, heritage and history.</s>

en: Zanzibar is far more than its beaches and luxury hotels — it’s a place bursting with talent that stems from an extraordinary history of cultural connection and collaboration.
yor: Zanzibar ju àwọn etíkun àti ilé ìtura olówó iyebíye rẹ̀ lọ — ó jẹ́ ibi tí ó kún fún àwọn ènìyàn ọlọ́pọlọ tí ó ní ẹ̀bùn ní poolo orí wọn látàrí àjọṣepọ̀ ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí ó mú agbègbè náà dá yàtọ̀ gedegbe.
mt0: <pad> Zanzibar ni o pọ̀ ju awọn ọ̀nà ìsìnkú àti àwọn ilé ìtura lójú òkèrè lọ — o jẹ́ ibi tí ó ní talenti tó ń yí kúrò nínú ìtàn ìbáṣepọ̀ àti ìṣòro.</s>

en: Editor's note: The author of this post has volunteered with DCMA.
yor: Ìfiyèsí Alákòóso Ìwé Títẹ̀: Òǹkọ̀wé àtẹ́jádé yìí ti ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀fẹ́ pẹ̀lú DCMA.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe ìwé ìsègùn rẹ̀. Ṣe ìsègùn rẹ̀ ní ìsègùn àtijọ́.</s>

en: Witch-hunting still claims lives in rural India
yor: Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ṣì ń gba ẹ̀mí àwọn ènìyàn ní ìgbèríko India
mt0: <pad> Witch-hunting still claims lives in rural areas.</s>

en: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
yor: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
mt0: <pad> Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India</s>

en: A village near Jamshedpur in Jharkhand. Picture courtesy Anumeha Verma
yor: Ìletò kan ní ẹ̀báa Jamshedpur ní Jharkhand. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Anumeha Verma
mt0: <pad> A village near Jamshedpur in Jharkhand. Picture courtesy Anumeha Verma</s>

en: On 20 July, four elderly people were lynched by a mob in the Gumla District of Jharkhand, India after being accused of practicing witchcraft.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Agẹmọ, àgbájọ àwọn ènìyànkéènìà gba ẹ̀mí àwọn àgbàlagbà mẹ́rin kan láì dá wọn lẹ́jọ́ ní agbègbèe Gumla ní Jharkhand, India lẹ́yìn tí a fi ẹ̀sùn-un àjẹ́ kàn wọ́n.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ́</s>

en: According to reports, the victims were accused of causing a man's death and they were eventually found guilty of witchcraft by a Panchayat (a village assembly).
yor: Gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn, àwọn àgbàlagbà wọ̀nyí ṣe ikú pa ọkùnrin kan, ni ìgbìmọ̀ abúlée Panchayat ṣe dá wọn lẹ́bi.
mt0: <pad> According to reports, the victims were accused of causing a man's death and they were eventually found guilty of witchcraft by a Panchayat (a village assembly).</s>

en: The victims were dragged out of their homes and beaten to death by masked men wielding sticks.
yor: Wọ́n wọ́ àwọn àgbàlagbà mẹ́rin wọ̀nyí jáde síta ilée wọn, àwọn ọkùnrin tí ó bòjú sì fi igi lù wọ́n títí tí ẹ̀mí fi bọ́ lára wọn.
mt0: <pad> Òkú àwọn ìdílé ni wọ́n ti gbé kúrò ní ilé wọn àti kọ́ wọn sílẹ̀ nípasẹ̀ àwọn ọkunrin tó fi aṣọ yí àwọn ọkùnrin tó ń sìn àwọn ìgbìmọ̀.</s>

en: Eight of the attackers were subsequently arrested by police.
yor: Mẹ́jọ nínú àwọn ènìyànkéènìà wọ̀nyí ti wà ní akóló ọlọ́pàá.
mt0: <pad> Eight of the attackers were later arrested by police.</s>

en: According to police data published by The Times of India, witch-hunting in Jharkhand has claimed 123 lives from May 2016 to May 2019.
yor: Gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí àkọsílẹ̀ ọlọ́pàá tí Times of India tẹ̀jáde, ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ní Jharkhand ti rán àwọn ènìyàn 123 sọ́run àpàpàǹdodo ní àárín-in oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2016 sí oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2019.
mt0: <pad> According to police data published by The Times of India, witch-hunting in Jharkhand has claimed 123 lives from May 2016 to May 2019.</s>

en: Across the country, 134 people were killed for the alleged use of "black magic" in 2016, according to the National Crime Records Bureau.
yor: Jákèjádò, ènìyàn 134 di ẹni ẹbọra-ń-bá-jẹun látàrí èsùn-un lílo “ògùngùn” ní ọdún-un 2016, ìyẹn gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí Àjọ Aṣàkọsílẹ̀ Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà ṣe kọ́ ọ sílẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Around the country, 134 people were killed for allegedly using "black magic" in 2016, according to the National Crime Records Bureau.</s>

en: A Perpetual Malady
yor: Àrùn T’ó Ń Peléke Sí i
mt0: <pad> A Perpetual Malady</s>

en: "Witch-hunting is not new in Jharkhand", says Prem Chand, the Founding Chairman of the Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand, in a telephonic interview.
yor: "Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ kò jẹ́ tuntun ní Jharkhand", Prem Chand, Olúdásílẹ̀ àti Alága Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) ní Jharkhand, sọ nínúu ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀ro-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> Witch-hunting is not new in Jharkhand, says Prem Chand, the Founding Chairman of the Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand in a telephonic interview.</s>

en: FLAC has been instrumental in bringing about legislation against witch-hunting in Jharkhand.
yor: FLAC ti ń ṣe àtọ́nàa ìṣòfin tí ó tako ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ní Jharkhand.
mt0: <pad> FLAC ti ṣe ipa ni ṣiṣe ofin lori ìgbàgbọ́ ẹ̀yìn ìṣọ́ ìwòye ní Jharkhand.</s>

en: The organisation first began working in this area in 1991 when a woman was accused by her neighbour of causing a boy’s death.
yor: Iléeṣẹ́ náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ní agbègbè yìí ní ọdún-un 1991 nígbà tí àwọn aládùúgbò fi ẹ̀sùn kan obìnrin kan pé ó lọ́wọ́ nínú ikú ọmọdékùnrin kan.
mt0: <pad> Ọ̀gbẹ́ àkọ́kọ́ ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ṣiṣẹ́ ní agbègbè náà lọ́dún 1991 lẹ́yìn tí ọmọdé kan ti a sọ pé o ti kú nípasè ìdílé rẹ̀.</s>

en: An irate mob attacked her and killed her husband and son.
yor: Àgbájọ àwọn ènìyànkéènìà kan dìgbò lù ú, wọ́n sì pa ọkọ àti ọmọ rẹ̀ ọkùnrin.
mt0: <pad> A riot attacked her and killed her husband and son.</s>

en: She sustained injuries.
yor: Òún fi ara pa.
mt0: <pad> Òun ti ní ìṣẹ́gun.</s>

en: When Prem Chand and his colleagues visited the offenders in the prison, they were met with defiance:
yor: Nígbàtí Prem Chand àti àwọn ẹlẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ ṣe ìbẹ̀wò sí àwọn ẹlẹ́ṣẹ̀ wọ̀nyí nínúu túbú, wọ́n bá ìpèníjà:
mt0: <pad> When Prem Chand and his colleagues visited the offenders in the prison, they were met with defiance.</s>

en: They told us that they stood by their accusation.
yor: Wọ́n sọ fún wọn wípé àwọn dúró lé oríi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kan àwọn.
mt0: <pad> Òun sọ fún wa pé ó dúró lórí ìbò wọn.</s>

en: They also shared a belief that when the blood of a woman branded as a witch falls on the ground, she loses her so-called powers of sorcery.
yor: Wọ́n sì tún gbàgbọ́ wípé bí ẹ̀jẹ̀ẹ ẹni tí a pè ní àjẹ́ bá kan ilẹ̀ ọ̀gẹ́rẹ́, yóò pàdánù agbára ẹlẹyẹ rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> They also shared a belief that when the blood of a woman branded as a wizard falls on the ground, she loses her so-called powers of sorcery.</s>

en: Prem Chand says that it affects specific sectors of the population:
yor: Prem Chand sọ wípé ó kan apá kan nínú àwọn ọmọ ìlú:
mt0: <pad> Prem Chand says that it affects specific sectors of the population.</s>

en: Usually, it is the women from the weaker sections of the society and economically backward regions that are targeted.
yor: Nígbàgbogbo, àwọn obìnrin tí kò lárá tí ó tálákà ní í máa ń fi ara kááṣá.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: The victims are mostly Adivasis, Harijans and Dalits.
yor: Àwọn tí ó f’ara kááṣá wọ̀nyí ni àwọn Adivasis, Harijans àti Dalits.
mt0: <pad> Awọn ìdílé ni o wa ni ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Adivasis, Harijans àti Dalits.</s>

en: It is an assault on the dignity of women and a violation of constitutional rights for a dignified life for every human being.
yor: Ìfojú iyì àwọn obìnrin àti ìtasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin ẹ̀tọ́ sí ayé iyì fún gbogbo ọmọ ènìyàn.
mt0: <pad> Èyí jẹ́ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ó ní àwọn obìnrin nínú ìgbésí àti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tó ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ ìlú àti ìtọ́jú àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ ìlú fún gbogbo ènìyàn.</s>

en: The Social and Political Realities
yor: Òtítọ́ Àwùjọ àti Ìṣèlú
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ awọn ọrọ rẹ?</s>

en: Activists say that deeply rooted superstitions prevalent in the hinterlands are a major cause behind the practice.
yor: Àwọn ajìjàngbara sọ wípé ìgbàgbọ́-asán tí ó rinlẹ̀ ní ìgbèríko ni ó ń fa ìwà pálapalà náà.
mt0: <pad> Activists say that deep-rooted superstitions prevalent in the hinterlands are a major reason behind the practice.</s>

en: A lack of education, poor health facilities and economic backwardness mark the regions where these practices are prevalent.
yor: Àìgbẹ̀kọ́, ètò ìlera tí ò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti kòlàkòṣagbe tí ó ń gb’àgbègbè tí ìwà pálapalà wọ̀nyí ti gbalẹ̀ bí i ìtàkùn ni ó fi wọ́pọ̀.
mt0: <pad> A lack of education, poor health facilities and economic backwardness mark the regions where these practices are prevalent.</s>

en: The cases so far show that often a rumor started by someone is enough to get the ball rolling.
yor: Ọ̀ràn wọ̀nyí ti fi hàn wípé àhesọ ni ó máa fi ń bẹ̀rẹ̀ .
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ó ti sẹ́yìn fi hàn pé àwọn ìròyìn tí a bẹ̀rẹ̀ láti ọ̀kan ní o jẹ́ kí wọ́n bẹ̀rẹ̀ ìrìnnà.</s>

en: Despite the laws enacted by various Indian states which declare witch-hunting to be illegal, participants in these cases see it as a form of self-defense.
yor: Pẹ̀lú òfin àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ India tí ó ka ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ sí ohun tí ó lòdì sófin, àwọn akópa ọ̀ràn wọ̀nyí rí i gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀nà ìdáààbò-ara-ẹni.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: It is also used as an excuse for grabbing resources owned by women, exacting revenge or even exploiting women for sex.
yor: Bákan náà ni wọ́n ń wí àwáwí fún gbígba ohun ìní àwọn obìnrin, fi agbára gbẹ̀san tàbí fi ipá bá obìnrin lò pọ̀.
mt0: <pad> O tun n lo bi idi fun gbigba awọn ohun-ini ti awọn obinrin ni, lati gba ẹsan, tabi lati lo awọn obinrin fun ibalopọ.</s>

en: According to Prem Chand:
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Prem Chand ṣe ti sọ:
mt0: <pad> According to Prem Chand:</s>

en: The premise is that once you brand a woman as a witch, you can subject her to any treatment.
yor: Àtètèròtẹ́lẹ̀ ni wípé ní kété tí o bá ti pe obìnrin ní àjẹ́, o lè tẹríi rẹ̀ ba fún ìlòkulò.
mt0: <pad> Ìyàtọ̀ náà ni pé lẹ́yìn tí o ti dán obìnrin kan sí ìwòsàn, o le fi ọ̀nà mọ́ nípa ohun gbogbo.</s>

en: However, it is important to note that the practice is used as a justification for exploitation and is not a cause behind it per se.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, ó ṣe kókó láti mọ̀ wípé wọn máa ń lo ìwà pálapàla yìí fi gba tara àwọn obìnrin, kò sì kìí ṣe ìdí tí ó ń fà á pàtó.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn, o ṣe pataki lati ṣe akiyesi pe a lo ilana naa ni idi fun iṣeduro ati pe o jẹ ohun ti o wa lẹhin rẹ per se.</s>

en: Ironically, the panchayat often provides tacit approval for branding a person a witch even if does not pass ruling on the punishment to be meted out.
yor: Ní ti ẹ̀fẹ̀, láì wí tó, panchayat náà sábà máa ń lọ́wọ́ sí ìpènìyàn ní àjẹ́ pàápàá bí kò bá pàṣẹ ìjìyà t'ó tọ́.
mt0: <pad> Ironically, the panchayat often provides tacit approval for branding a person a witch even if it does not pass ruling on the punishment to be meted out.</s>

en: In addition to the elected panchayat, there are self-styled caste panchayats with no legal mandate whatsoever that operate in certain parts of the country.
yor: Ní àfikùn sí panchayat tí ìbó yàn, àwọn kan ńbẹ tí wọ́n pe ara wọn ní panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ láì ní àṣẹ kankan tí ó fún wọn lágbara níbikíbi ní orílẹ̀-èdè.
mt0: <pad> Àti àwọn ìgbéjọ́ ìṣọ́lẹ̀, àwọn ìgbéjọ́ ẹ̀yà ìṣọ́lẹ̀ ti o ní ìṣẹ́ òfin kò sí n ṣiṣẹ́ ni àwọn agbègbè kan.</s>

en: These bodies pass verdicts and mete out punishments and remain largely unchallenged.
yor: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ yìí máa ń dájọ́ àti fi ìyà jẹ ènìyàn tí kò sì sí ẹni tí ó ká wọn lápá kò.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìjọba yìí n ṣe àṣẹ àti sọ̀wọ́ ẹ̀ṣẹ̀, àti wọ́n sì jẹ́ kí a máa sọrọ̀ nípa wọn.</s>

en: An incident in Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported involvement of caste panchayat leading to the death of a 40-year-old woman.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan ní agbègbèe Ajmer ní Rajasthan lọ́dún-un 2017 jábọ̀ ìlọ́wọ́sí panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ tí ó ṣ’okùnfa ikú obìnrin ogójì ọdún kan.
mt0: <pad> A ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ni Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported involvement of caste panchayat leading to the death of a 40-year-old woman.</s>

en: Legally, the courts can take action against such verdicts in case of both elected panchayats and caste panchayats.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí òfin, ilé ẹjọ́ lé gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó tako irúu ìdájọ́ báwọ̀nyí yálà láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn panchayat tí ìbó yàn àti panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Òfin, ilé ẹjọ́ le ṣe ìgbésí nípa àwọn ìdájọ́ bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ọ̀nà àwọn ìdìbò àti àwọn ìdìbò àṣà.</s>

en: However, the victims seldom get the opportunity to reach a court of law before they become targets of mobs.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àwọn tí ó fara kááṣá ò tilẹ̀ ní àǹfààní sí ilé-ẹjọ́ òfin kí àgbájọ-àwọn-ènìyànkéènìà ó tó kojúu wọn.
mt0: <pad> However, the victims seldom get the opportunity to reach a court of law before they become targets of mobs.</s>

en: Witch-hunting across India
yor: Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ jákèjádò India
mt0: <pad> Witch-hunting across the world</s>

en: Jharkhand has recorded the highest number of crimes committed in the name of witch-hunting but it is not the only state.
yor: Jharkhand ti ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ iye ẹṣẹ̀ àwọn ènìyán ṣẹ̀ tí ó pọ̀ jù lọ tí ó tan mọ́ ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ àmọ́ kì í ṣe ìpínlẹ̀ náà nìkan.
mt0: <pad> Jharkhand has recorded the highest number of crimes committed in the name of witch-hunting but it is not the only state.</s>

en: Cases of witch-hunting have been reported from Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra and Rajasthan too.
yor: Ọ̀ràn-an ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ti wà l’ákọsílẹ̀ ní Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra àti Rajasthan pẹ̀lú.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ?</s>

en: In a chilling incident in 2014, Debjani Bora, an Indian athlete had become a target in Assam.
yor: Nígbà ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan ní 2014, Debjani Bora, ẹlẹ́sẹ̀ ehoro ọmọ bíbíi orílẹ̀-èdèe India ti fi ara kááṣá rí.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: According to Debjani’s statements, she was accused of being the cause of several deaths in Cherekali village located 180 km from Guwahati, the capital of the eastern state in India.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀rọ̀ọ Debjani, a f’ẹ̀sùn-un ìgbẹ̀mí ènìyàn púpọ̀ kàn án ní abúlée Cherekali tí ó wà ní kìlómità 180 láti Guwahati, olú-ìlúu India ti apáa ìlà-oòrùn.
mt0: <pad> According to Debjani's statements, she was accused of being the cause of several deaths in Cherekali village located 180 km from Guwahati, the capital of the eastern state in India.</s>

en: She was allegedly named by a headman of a village prayer hall and brutally assaulted by the villagers.
yor: Olóríi gbọ̀gán àdúrà abúlé l’ó dárúkọ rẹ̀ tí àwọn ará abúlé sí fi ìyà jẹ́ ẹ.
mt0: <pad> Òun ti sọ pé ó ti ní orúkọ àwọn ọmọ-ìdílé ìjọsìn ìlú àti pe wọ́n ti ṣe ìṣẹ̀gun rẹ̀ nípasè àwọn ará ìdílé.</s>

en: 2017 witnessed several cases in the state of Rajasthan.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ 2017 ní ipínlẹ̀ Rajasthan.
mt0: <pad> 2017 witnessed several cases in the state of Rajasthan.</s>

en: Among these, a 40-year-old woman Kanya Devi was attacked and beaten to death after being accused by her family members in Ajmer district of the state.
yor: Lára èyí ni, ọmọbìnrin ogójì ọdún kan Kanya Devi rí ìkọlù tí a sì lù ú pa lẹ́yìn tí mọ̀lẹ́bíi rẹ̀ fi ẹ̀sùn kàn án ní agbègbèe Ajmer.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìyàtọ̀ nínú àwọn èyí, ọmọ ọdún 40 Kanya Devi ti a ṣe ìbọn àti ìṣẹ́gun lẹ́yìn tí àwọn ẹbí rẹ̀ fi sọ pé ó jẹ́ òṣèlú.</s>

en: Victims and Survivors
yor: Àwọn Ẹni-tó-fara-kááṣá àti Ẹni-tórí-kó-yọ
mt0: <pad> Òkú àti ìgbàlà.</s>

en: People blame accused witches for causing a slew of misfortunes: the death of a person or animal, droughts, crop failures, etc.
yor: Àwọn ènìyàn ń f’ẹ̀sùn kan àwọn ẹlẹyẹ fún iṣẹ́-ibi ọwọ́ọ wọn: ikú ènìyàn tàbí ẹranko, ọ̀dá òjò, àìso jìngbìnnì irúgbìn, àti bẹ́èbẹ́è lọ.
mt0: <pad> Awon eyan ma n fi idibo si awon olori ogbon fun a slew of misfortunes: iku eniyan tabi ẹranko, ojo riro, aisan irugbin, ati be be lo.</s>

en: The attacks on these women (and some men) are vicious and inhuman.
yor: Ìkọlù tí ó kọ lu àwọn obìnrin wọ̀nyí (àti àwọn ọkùnrin kan) rorò bí ẹranko ẹhànnà.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ lórí àwọn obìnrin (àti àwọn ọkùnrin) ni ìyàtọ̀ àti òdodo.</s>

en: At times, the accusations and punishment are meted out by their families.
yor: Nígbà mìíràn, àwọn èsùn náà àti ìjìyà ẹṣé máa wá láti ọ̀dọ̀ mọ̀lébíi wọn.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìgbà kan, ẹ̀ṣẹ́ àti ìdánwò ni wọ́n fi ṣe àwọn ìdílé wọn.</s>

en: Some have lived to tell the tale and fight. Chutni Mahato of Saraikela in Jharkhand is one of them.
yor: Àwọn kan ń gbé tí wọ́n sì ń sọ ìtàn-an wọn tí wọ́n sì ń jà fún ẹ̀tọ́ọ wọn.
mt0: <pad> Awọn kan ti n gbe lati sọ itan naa ati lati ja. Chutni Mahato of Saraikela in Jharkhand is one of them.</s>

en: People from the region call her a "tigress".
yor: Chutni Mahato ti Saraikela ní Jharkhand jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára wọn.
mt0: <pad> People from the region call her a "tigress".</s>

en: She was accused of practicing witchcraft in 1995.
yor: Àwọn ènìyàn láti agbègbè náà máa ń pè é ní "tigress".
mt0: <pad> Òun ní ìyàwó ìgbàlódé ọ̀nà ìṣòwò ní 1995.</s>

en: Since then, she has transformed into an activist crusading against the victimization of women in the name of witch-hunting with the help of NGOs working to end the practice.
yor: Wọ́n fi ẹ̀sùn-un àjẹ́ kàn-án ní ọdún-un 1995. Láti ìgbà náà, ó ti yírapadà di ajìjàǹgbara olùtako ìfìyàjẹ àwọn obìnrin pẹ̀lú àtìléyìn Ilé-iṣẹ́-tí-kìí-ṣe-tìjọba.
mt0: <pad> Since then, she has transformed into an activist crusading against the victimization of women in the name of witch-hunting with the help of NGOs working to end the practice.</s>

en: Chutni expresses how the lack of resources often makes it a struggle to fight against the practice.
yor: Chutni sọ bí àìsí àtìlẹ́yìn tó késejárí ṣe mú u nira láti jà tako ìwà pálapàla yìí.
mt0: <pad> Chutni expresses how the lack of resources often makes it difficult to fight against the practice.</s>

en: I wish there was more support from the authorities and government for the work that we are doing here.
yor: Ìbájẹ́pé àtìlẹ́yìn tó tó wá láti ọwọ́ àwọn oníṣẹọba àti ìjọba fún iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe níbí.
mt0: <pad> I wish there was more support from the authorities and government for the work that we are doing here.</s>

en: However, I have suffered because of this practice.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, mo ti jìyà nítorí ìwà pálapàla yìí.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn, Mo ti jiya nitori eyi.</s>

en: When someone comes to me for help, I am always going to stand by them, she said in a telephonic interview.
yor: Bí ènìyàn bá tọ̀ mí wá fún ìrànlọ́wọ́, mo máa dúró tì wọ́n gbágbágbá, ó sọ nínúu ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀ro-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> When someone comes to me for help, I'm always going to stand by them, she said in a telephonic interview.</s>

en: Formulating Public Opinion
yor: Dídá Ohùn Gbogboògbò Sí i
mt0: <pad> Ṣe atunṣe awọn ọmọde gbogbogbo.</s>

en: Both the survivors and activists feel that there is a lack of public opinion in support of ending witch-hunting.
yor: Àwọn ẹni-tórí-kó-yọ àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́-ènìyàn rò wípé àwọn ènìyàn gbogbo kò ti ìfòpin sí ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ lẹ́yìn.
mt0: <pad> Both the survivors and activists feel that there is a lack of public opinion in support of ending witch-hunting.</s>

en: The activists who were interviewed for this story expressed a paucity of political will and intellectual engagement to provide the momentum required for the campaign against the heinous practice to succeed.
yor: Àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́-ènìyàn tí a fọ̀rọ̀ wá lẹ́nu wò lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí jẹ́ kí á mọ̀ wípé àbùkù ìrànwọ́ ìjọba àti àwọn onímọ̀ ni kò mú ìwà àìbójúmu náà ṣíra kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> activists who were interviewed for this story expressed a paucity of political will and intellectual engagement to provide the momentum required for the campaign against the heinous practice to succeed.</s>

en: A silver lining in this dark cloud is that people working against the practice believe that the situation can be turned around.
yor: Ohun tí ó dára jù lọ ni wípé àwọn tí ó ń tako ìwà burúkú yìí gbàgbọ́ wípé àyípadà lè dé.
mt0: <pad> A silver lining in this dark cloud is that people working against the practice believe that the situation can be turned around.</s>

en: According to Prem Chand:
yor: Ní ọ̀rọ̀ọ Prem Chand:
mt0: <pad> According to Prem Chand:</s>

en: The efforts for ending witch hunting can be modeled on the same principles that the government has used for promoting other social problems such as the literacy mission.
yor: Akitiyan láti f’òpin sí ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ lè tẹ̀lé ìlànà tí ìjọba fi polongo ètò mímọ̀ọ-kọ-àti-mímọ̀ọ-kà.
mt0: <pad> Ìgbésẹ̀ láti yọ́n ìwà ìsìnkú àwọn ìṣòkò ìlú lè jẹ́ ìdánwò lórí àwọn ìlànà tí àjọba ti lo láti ṣe ìṣẹ́gun àwọn ìṣòro ìdílé míràn bí ìṣẹ́gun ìmọ̀lẹ̀.</s>

en: Also, the intellectuals would have to lend their support to the cause to mold the public opinion.
yor: Bákan náà, àwọn onímọ̀ ní láti f’ọwọ́ sí i k’áwọn ènìyàn ó ba f’ohùn sí i.
mt0: <pad> Also, the intellectuals would have to lend their support to the cause to mold the public opinion to mold the public opinion.</s>

en: The sources for the story were interviewed with the assistance of B. Vijay Murty, a journalist and resident editor based out of Jharkhand.
yor: B. Vijay Murty, akọ̀ròyìn àti olùgbé Jharkhand ni ó gbọ̀rọ̀ sílẹ̀ lẹ́nu àwọn tí ọ̀rọ́ kàn.
mt0: <pad> Ìwé ìròyìn náà ni wọ́n gbé nípa ìsègùn B. Vijay Murty, ọ̀gbẹ́ni àwọn akọ́ròyìn àti àgbéjáde àkọsílè àti ojúewé àtijọ́ ti Jharkhand.</s>

en: Caring for Myanmar’s orphaned elephants
yor: Ìtọ́jú àwọn erin aláìlóbìíi Myanmar
mt0: <pad> Ṣe atilẹyin awọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ elephants Myanmar àti ìyá wọn</s>

en: A camp staff member bottle-feeds Ayeyar Maung. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy
yor: Òṣìṣẹ́ àgọ̀ kan ń rọ Ayeyar Maung ní oúnjẹ. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy
mt0: <pad> A soldier bottle-feeds Ayeyar Maung. / Aung Kyaw Htet / The Irrawaddy</s>

en: This article by Aung Kyaw Htet is from The Irrawaddy, an independent news website in Myanmar, and is republished on Global Voices as part of a content-sharing agreement.
yor: Àpilẹ̀kọ jẹ́ ti Aung Kyaw Htet tí ó kọ́ fún The Irrawaddy, iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìnin orí ayélujára ní Myanmar, tí Ohùn Àgbáyé ṣe àtúntẹ̀jádée rẹ̀ ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àdéhùn ìbáṣepọ̀ tí ó wà láàárín wọn.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ ọgbọn rẹ?</s>

en: When forestry staff found her deep in the jungle of the Irrawaddy Delta, Ayeyar Sein was three months old.
yor: Nígbà tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ alábòójútó igbó rí i nínú ijù tí ó sún mọ́ Etí-omi Irrawaddy, oṣù mẹ́ta ni Ayeyar Sein nígbà náà.
mt0: <pad> When forestry staff found her deep in the jungle of the Irrawaddy Delta, Ayeyar Sein was three months old.</s>

en: One of her legs was caught in a steel trap laid by poachers.
yor: Ẹsẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ kan ti lu páḿpẹ́ àwọn ajérangbépa.
mt0: <pad> Ọ̀kan nínú ẹ̀sẹ̀ rẹ̀ ti wọ́n fi ṣe ìwọ̀n àwọn ọlọ́ja.</s>

en: Workers from the government’s timber extraction enterprise saved her and sent her to an elephant camp in Bago Region for treatment.
yor: Àwọn onígẹdú ìjọba ló dóòlà ẹ̀míi rẹ̀, wọ́n sì gbé e lọ sí àgọ́ erin kan ní Agbègbèe Bago fún ìtọ́jú.
mt0: <pad> Employees from the government's timber extraction enterprise saved her and sent her to an elephant camp in Bago Region for treatment.</s>

en: Now she is one of eight calves being sheltered at Wingabaw, Myanmar’s only elephant orphanage.
yor: Òhun ni ọ̀dọ̀ erin kẹjọ tí yóò rí ààbò ní Wingabaw, ibi ààbò fún àwọn erin Myanmar tí kò lóbìí.
mt0: <pad> Agba elephants ni Myanmar.</s>

en: Another calf, Ayeyar Maung, endured a similar ordeal.
yor: Ọ̀dọ́ erin mìíràn, Ayeyar Maung náà rí nǹkan.
mt0: <pad> Another calf, Ayeyar Maung, endured a similar ordeal.</s>

en: Before his arrival at the camp, the six-month-old was snared in a wire trap.
yor: Kí ó tó di èròo àgọ́ náà, erin oṣù mẹ́fà náà ti lu okùn.
mt0: <pad> Before he arrived at the camp, the six-month-old was snared in a wire trap.</s>

en: As he was stuck among a group of boulders in the same forest where Ayeyar Sein was found, his herd was forced to leave him behind.
yor: Ó sì há sí àárín àwọn òkúta nínú ijù kan náà tí a ti rí Ayeyar Sein, àwọn ọ̀wọ́ọ rẹ̀ tó kù fi í sílẹ̀ lọ.
mt0: <pad> When he was caught among a group of boulders in the same forest where Ayeyar Sein was found, his herd was forced to leave him behind.</s>

en: However, forest workers were able to free him and he arrived at the camp last year.
yor: Síbẹ̀, àwọn alábòójútó ijù tú u sílẹ̀, ó sì di aráa àgọ́ náà ní ọdún tó kọjá.
mt0: <pad> However, forest workers were able to free him and he arrived at the camp last year.</s>

en: They are the youngest of the orphans at the camp; the oldest is nearly four years their senior.
yor: Àwọn méjèèjì ni erin aláìlóbìíi tí ó kéré jù lọ nínú àgọ́ náà; ọdún mẹ́rin ni erin tí ó dàgbà jù gbà lọ́wọ́ọ wọn.
mt0: <pad> They are the youngest of the orphans at the camp; the oldest is nearly four years their senior.</s>

en: All have tragic backgrounds.
yor: Gbogbo wọn ni ó ní ìtàn kan tàbí òmíràn tí ó jẹ mọ́ ìjìyà láti ọwọ́ ẹ̀dá ọmọ ènìyàn adáríhununrun.
mt0: <pad> Everyone has a sad background.</s>

en: Some were left by their herds, while others were orphaned when their parents were killed by poachers.
yor: Àwọn kan kò rí ọ̀wọ́ọ wọn tí wọ́n jọ ń jẹ̀ mọ́, àwọn mìíì di aláìlóbìíi lẹ́yìn tí àwọn tí ó ń pa ẹran nínú ìgbẹ́ nípakúpa pa òbíi wọn.
mt0: <pad> Awọn kan ni a ti fi sile nipasẹ awọn ọgba, awọn miiran si ni awọn ọmọde nigbati awọn obi wọn ni awọn oluwa ṣe idapo.</s>

en: At Wingabaw Camp, the motherless calves rely on baby formula provided daily by staff.
yor: Ní àgọ́ tí ó wà ní Wingabaw, àwọn ọ̀dọ́ erin tí kò ní òbí náà gbẹ́kẹ̀lé oúnjẹ ọmọ ìkókó tí àwọn alábòójútó ijù ń pèsè fún wọn lójoojúmọ́.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ọmọ ìdílé àtijọ́ ni Wingabaw Camp, nínú àwọn ọmọ ìdílé àtijọ́, wọ́n gbà àwọn ọmọ ìdílé àtijọ́ lórí àwọn ohun ìtọ́jú àtijọ́ lójoojumọ̀.</s>

en: They are allowed to roam in the forest in the morning and wash in a nearby stream before returning to the camp.
yor: Ààyé gbà wọ́n láti jẹ̀ nínú ijù ní òwúrò, wọn yóò sì wẹ̀ nínú odò kékeré kan nítòsí kí wọn ó tó padà sí àgọ́.
mt0: <pad> They are allowed to roam in the forest in the morning and wash in a nearby stream before returning to the camp.</s>

en: Currently, it is believed that Myanmar has nearly 1,500 wild elephants.
yor: Lọ́wọ́ lọ́wọ́ báyìí, Myanmar yóò fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ ní tó erin ẹgàn 1,500.
mt0: <pad> Currently, it is believed that Myanmar has nearly 1,500 wild elephants.</s>

en: But they are under serious threat from poaching, with elephants being killed at the alarming rate of one a week.
yor: Àmọ́ ó jẹ́ ohun tí ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́ nítorí pé àwọn tí ó ń dá ẹ̀míi wọn légbodò kò jẹ́ kí wọn ó gbé ayé, erin kan lọ́sẹ̀ kan ni wọ́n ń pa.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn wọn wa labẹ ìyàlẹ̀ nípa ìjàbọ̀, pẹlú ẹranko ọ̀fẹ́ ńlá tí wọ́n ń pa ni ìṣòro ní ìgbà kan lóṣù kẹta.</s>

en: Tobago's coral bleaching alert makes it clear there is ‘no alternative’ to fighting the climate crisis
yor: Iyùn Tobago tí ó ti ń pàwọ̀dà fi hàn gbàgàdàgbagada pé kò sí ọ̀nà mìíràn ju kíkojú àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́
mt0: <pad> Tobago's coral bleaching alert makes it clear there is ‘no alternative’ to combating the climate change</s>

en: The island's reefs are on "Bleaching Alert Level One"
yor: The island's reefs are on "Bleaching Alert Level One"
mt0: <pad> Òkè ìlú náà ni ó wà lórí "Ìkún ìmọ́lẹ̀ ìwọ̀n ìgbà kan"</s>

en: Bleached stag horn coral. Photo by Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.
yor: Iyùn bí ìwo àgbọ̀nrín tí ó ti pàwọ̀dà. Àworán láti ọwọ́ọ Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.
mt0: <pad> Bleached stag horn coral. Photo by Matt Kieffer, CC BY-SA 2.0.</s>

en: Tobago's coral reefs are an integral part of both the island's marine ecosystem and its economy.
yor: Iyùn-un abẹ́ òkúta òkun jẹ́ ohun tí a ò leè fọwọ́ rọ́ sẹ́yìn nínú àwọn àmúṣọrọ̀ tí ó ń mú ọrọ̀ Ajé Tobago àti àwọn àyíká erékùṣù náà gbòòrò.
mt0: <pad> Ìyàtọ̀ ìsìnkú àwọn ẹja òkun Tobago jẹ́ apá kan pàtàkì nínú àgbáyé àti ọrọ̀ ajé rẹ̀.</s>

en: Home to numerous species of marine life (and a main source of fish for local fishermen), they also protect the coastline from wave erosion and the effects of tropical storms.
yor: Ibùgbé ọ̀kan-òjọ̀kan ẹ̀yà ẹ̀dá inú omi (àti ibi ẹja pípa fún àwọn apẹja ìbílẹ̀), tí ó sì tún ń dá ààbò bo èbúté, èyí tí kò mú kí àwọn ìjì líle etí omi ó pọ̀ kọjá àlà ni à ń sọ.
mt0: <pad> Home to numerous species of marine life (and a major source of fish for local fishermen), they also protect the coastline from wave erosion and the effects of tropical storms.</s>

en: Popular spots like Buccoo Reef are also popular tourist attractions.
yor: Òkúta inú òkun Buccoo Reef tí o gbajúmọ̀ bí ìṣáná ẹlẹ́ta tí àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ máa ń wọ́ tùùrùtù níbẹ̀ náà kò gbẹ́yìn.
mt0: <pad> Popular spots like Buccoo Reef are also popular tourist attractions.</s>

en: But after a press release issued by the country's Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) on August 22, 2019, in which it warned that — based on findings from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch — Tobago's coral reefs have been placed on a watch for "Bleaching Alert Level One", all eyes are on the island.
yor: Àmọ́ lẹ́yìn àtẹ̀jáde kan sí ilé ìròyìn tí Àjọ tí ó ń ṣàkóso Omi orílẹ̀ èdè náà (IMA) tẹ̀ jáde ní ọjọ́ 22, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2019, èyí tí ó kìlọ̀ wípé – ìwádìíi National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch sọ wípé — iyùn abẹ́ òkúta òkun Tobago ti bọ́ sì abẹ́ ìṣọ́ láti ṣe òfíntótó "Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dàa Ìpele Ìkíni", gbogbo ojú ló ń wo erékùṣù náà.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn lẹhin ti awọn iroyin ti awọn Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) ti o wa ni August 22, 2019, ninu eyiti o sọ pe — lori awọn awari lati National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch — Tobago's coral reefs have been placed on a watch for "Bleaching Alert Level One", gbogbo oju wa si ìlú.</s>

en: There is a distinct possibility that the bleaching could advance to Level Two within a matter of weeks, which would threatens not only the existence of the reefs themselves, but also the island's marine life and people.
yor: A ì í ṣe é mọ̀, ìpàwọ̀dà náà lè fò fẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ìpele kejì láàárín ọ̀sẹ̀ díẹ̀, tí yóò sì fa àkóbá fún ìwàláàyè àwọn iyùn wọ̀nyí, àwọn ẹ̀dá inú omi mìíràn àti àwọn olùgbé erékùṣù náà.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe awọn anfani ti o han pe bleaching le lọ si Ipele II laarin ọsẹ diẹ, eyi ti yoo ṣe ìyàtọ̀ nípa ìgbésí rẹ̀, ṣugbọn kò ṣe ìgbésí àwọn reef nikan, ṣugbọn àwọn ẹranko òkun àti àwọn ènìyàn ìlú.</s>

en: What exactly is bleaching?
yor: Kí ni ohun tí ń pàwọ̀dà ní pàtó?
mt0: <pad> Bleaching ni ohun ti o jẹ?</s>

en: Corals coexist with and become home to symbiotic algae, helping it store nutrients and remove waste.
yor: Alábàágbé àti alájọṣe iyùn ni àwọn ewé inú omi tí ó máa ń bá a kó ohun aṣaralóore pamọ́ àti da èérí ara nù.
mt0: <pad> Corals coexist with and become home to symbiotic algae, helping it store nutrients and remove waste.</s>

en: In return, the algae gives the coral the energy it needs to grow, but drastic changes in water temperature can threaten this cooperative relationship.
yor: Ewé wọ̀nyí yóò sì fún iyùn ní okun tí ó nílò fún ìdàgbàsókè, àmọ́ àyípadà ìgbóná inú omi ń dí àjọṣepọ̀ yìí lọ́wọ́.
mt0: <pad> À ìåíÿ, àwọn ẹ̀wà yí kórò ní agbára tí ó ní láti gbé, ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ayípadà ìsìnkú omi le ṣe ìṣòro ìbámu ìgbésẹ̀ yìí.</s>

en: When water becomes too hot (or too cold) the corals expel the algae — and with it, its main source of food.
yor: Bí omi bá gbóná ju bí ó ṣe yẹ lọ (tàbí bí ó bá tutù jù) àwọn iyùn yóò lé ewé omi — tí yóò sì pàdánù ọwọ́ tí ó ń fi oúnjẹ nù ún.
mt0: <pad> When the water becomes too hot (or too cold), the corals expel the algae — and with it, its main source of food.</s>

en: Eventually, the coral starves to death; the most noticeable outward sign of this phenomenon is that the coral loses its colour, going from shades of brown and green to a crisp, brittle, bone white.
yor: Àṣèyìnwá àṣẹ̀yìnbọ̀, ebi yóò pa iyùn kú; àwọ̀ ara tí yóò yí padà ni àmì tí a ó fi mọ̀, ìpàwọ̀dà láti àwọ̀ olómi-ọkà àti ewéko sí funfun egungun.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìgbà kan, awọn ẹja corals kú; ìyẹn jẹ́ ìrírí tó lè ṣe ìwòye nípa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà ni pé ẹja corals n sọwọ́ ara rẹ̀, o lọ́ lati awọ brown àti green sí a crisp, brittle, bone white.</s>

en: Bleaching Level Alert One means that the corals are extremely likely to start the bleaching process.
yor: Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dà Ìpele Kìíní ń kéde wípé bí a kò bá wá nǹkan ṣe sí i, àwọn iyùn náà yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í pàwọ̀dà.
mt0: <pad> Bleaching Level Alert One means that the corals are extremely likely to start the bleaching process.</s>

en: The IMA therefore suggests that both biologists and citizens should keep an eye out for signs of bleaching over the next 9-12 weeks.
yor: IMA dábàá wípé kí àwọn onímọ̀ ìṣẹ̀dá àti ọmọ ìlú ó máa ṣọ́ àwọn ẹ̀dá inú omi náà fún àwọn àmì ìpàwọ̀dà ní àárín-in ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́sàn-án sí méjìlá tí ó ń bọ̀.
mt0: <pad> IMA therefore suggests that both biologists and citizens should keep an eye out for signs of bleaching over the next 9-12 weeks.</s>

en: Level Two bleaching would be an indication of widespread coral bleaching and coral mortality.
yor: Ìpele ìpàwọ̀dà kejì yóò jẹ́ ìtọ́ka sí ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn kárí ayé àti ikú iyùn.
mt0: <pad> Ìyàwó ìgbà kejì jẹ́ ìjábọ̀ ìyàwó coral àti ìyàwó coral.</s>

en: What causes it?
yor: Kí ló fa sábàbí?
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ́ ìdí tí ó mú kí o ṣẹlẹ̀.</s>

en: According to local coral reef ecologist Anjani Ganase, the main contributors to coral bleaching in Tobago are the warmer water temperatures — a result of climate change.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí onímọ̀ àyíká ìbílẹ̀ Anjani Ganase ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, ọ̀dádá tí ó dá ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn-un Tobago ni ìwọ̀n ìgbóná omi tí ó re òkè — tí í ṣe arapa àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.
mt0: <pad> According to local coral reef ecologist Anjani Ganase, the main contributors to coral bleaching in Tobago are the warmer water temperatures — a result of climate change.</s>

en: Via email, Ganase explained that the ocean absorbs much of the heat in the atmosphere, which in turn causes the water — especially shallower bodies of water, like the Caribbean Sea — to heat up.
yor: Nínú ímeèlì, Ganase ṣàlàyé wípé òkun máa ń fa èyí tí ó pọ̀ nínú ooru inú afẹ́fẹ́ mu, tí ó sì ń fa kí omi — pàápàá jù lọ àwọn ibú omi jínjìn gbungbunrungbun bíi Ọ̀sàa Caribbean — ó gbóná janjan.
mt0: <pad> Via email, Ganase explained that the ocean absorbs much of the heat in the atmosphere, which in turn causes the water — especially shallower bodies of water, like the Caribbean Sea — to heat up.</s>

en: In fact, NOAA's 12-week outlook extends well past Tobago to the reefs of the Lesser Antilles.
yor: Kódà, ìṣọ́ ọlọ́sẹ̀ méjìláa NOAA Tobago tan pinpin àyípadà yìí dé iyùn Lesser Antilles.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn, NOAA's 12-week outlook extends well past Tobago to the reefs of the Lesser Antilles.</s>

en: Other reefs around the region, most notably in parts of the Greater Antilles and Cuba, have already been placed on a Level Two Bleaching Alert:
yor: Àwọn òkúta tí ó wà ní agbègbè náà, bíi Greater Antilles àti Cuba, ti wà ní Ìpele Kejì Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dà:
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: What are its effects?
yor: Kí ni arapa rẹ̀?
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀ ìyàtọ́ rẹ̀.</s>

en: Coral bleaching is a huge threat.
yor: Ohun tí ó léwu ni ìpàwọ̀dàa iyùn.
mt0: <pad> Coral bleaching is a big danger.</s>

en: Because reefs provide fishes with a habitat that allows them to have access to shelter, food and most importantly, shelter for their young until they are ready to survive in the wider ocean, the proposition of losing them will impact the ability of fish species to survive.
yor: Nítorí wípé iyùn máa fún ẹja ní oúnjẹ, òun náà ni ó dúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé fún àwọn ẹja àti fún àwọn ọmọ ẹja tí kòì tíì lè wẹ̀ nínú alagbalúgbú omi, nítorí ìdí èyí, bí a bá pàdánùu wọn, ẹja náà yóò bá wọn lọ.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀</s>

en: It will also negatively affect the livelihoods of local fishermen.
yor: Bí ẹjá bá sì tán lómi, iṣẹ́ bọ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn apẹja nìyẹn.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: Tobago relies very heavily on its local tourism industry; its reefs reportedly attract around 40 per cent of the island's tourists.
yor: Tobago gbẹ́kẹ̀lé iléeṣẹ́ ìrìnàjò afẹ́ ìbílẹ̀; ìdá 40 àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ erékùṣù yìí ni ó máa ń wá láti wo àwọn iyùn omi wọ̀nyí.
mt0: <pad> Tobago relys very heavily on its local tourist industry; its reefs reportedly attract around 40 per cent of the island's tourists.</s>

en: Should coral bleaching continue, there will be fewer thriving reefs for people to explore and quite likely, a reduction in tourism dollars, which affects a range of hospitality-related industries: hotels, restaurants, transport services and tour companies.
yor: Bí ìpàwọ̀dà bá tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn ènìyàn kò ní rí òkúta iyùn, owó dollar ìrìnàjò afẹ́ yóò fìdí jálẹ̀, tí yóò sì kó bá àwọn iléeṣẹ́ agbàlejò bíi: ilé ìtura, ilé ìjẹun, iṣẹ́ ìgbòkègbodò ọkọ̀ àti ilé iṣẹ́ aṣàkóso ìrìnàjò.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe awọn ìgbàlódé coral tẹ́siwaju, o lè ní àwọn ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìgbàlódé ìlú láti ṣawari àti o ṣeéṣe àti ìyípadà nínú àwọn dọla ìrìnnà ìrìnnà, èyí tó lè ní ipa lórí àwọn ìṣàdúrà ìdílé: ilé ìtura, ilé ìtàgé, àwọn iṣẹ́ ìrìnnà àti àwọn ilé ìtàgé.</s>

en: The great irony is that, as tropical storms intensify as a result of the climate crisis, reefs are needed more than ever to absorb the force of waves and create a buffer between the ocean and the shore — but the reefs are compromised by global heating.
yor: Bí ìjì líle bá ń pọ̀ sí i látàrí ségesège ojú-ọjọ́, òkúta iyùn-ún níṣẹ́ pàtàkì ní ṣíṣe láti fa agbára àwọn ìgbé omi àti ìdúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí alárinà láàárín òkun àti etí òkun — àmọ́ ìgbóná àgbáńlá ayé ń dí i lọ́wọ́ láti ṣiṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Ìyàtọ̀ ìgbàlódé ni pé, bí ìjì líle ń pọ̀ sí nítorí ìsùn ìkìrò ayé, a gbọ́dọ̀ ní ìwọ̀n ìwò ní ìgbà tí ó ti wáyé láti gbà ìṣẹ́jú ìjì líle àti ìdádúró àti ìṣọ̀ àti ìlú — ṣùgbọ́n ìwò náà ní ìfẹ̀ àti ìmọ̀lẹ̀ àti ìyàtọ̀ àti ìmọ̀lẹ̀ àti ìyàtọ̀ àti ìlú.</s>

en: Studies show that coral reefs protect around 90 per cent of Tobago's shoreline from wave-induced erosion.
yor: Ìwádìí ti fi ìdíi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ wípé òkúta iyùn ní ń gba ìdá 90 etídò Tobago sílẹ̀-lọ́wọ́ ọ̀gbàrá tí ìgbé omi ń fà.
mt0: <pad> Ìwádìí fi hàn pé àwọn ìsìnkú òkun n sábà gbọ́ ní ìdá 90 àti ìdílé Tobago láti ìyọnu ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú rẹ̀ láti ìjì líle.</s>

en: In a feature address at the International Year of the Reef at the University of the West Indies in 2018, Professor John Agard said that this function will only become more important as storm intensities increase and sea levels rise.
yor: Ní ibi ètò Àyájọ́ Ọdún Òkúta iyùn ní Ifásitì West Indies ní ọdún-un 2018, Ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n John Agard sọ wípé iṣẹ́ yìí yóò pọ̀ sí i bí ìjì ṣe ń pọ̀ sí i àti bí ọ̀sà ṣe ń kún sókè.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ ọ?</s>

en: What can we do to stop it?
yor: Kí ni a lè ṣe láti dẹ́kun rẹ̀?
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀ ohun tí a le ṣe láti dẹ́ ìyẹn sílẹ̀?</s>

en: Ganase says the lack of proper management that has allowed overfishing and pollution to go unchecked has made Tobago's coral bleaching worse.
yor: Ganase ní pé àìmójútò omi wọ̀nyí bí ó ti tọ́ ló fa ẹja pípa kọjá àlà àti ìbàjẹ́ àyíká ni eku ẹdá tí ó fa ìpàwọ̀dà iyùn-un Tobago.
mt0: <pad> Ganase says the lack of proper management that has allowed overfishing and pollution to go unchecked has made Tobago's coral bleaching worse.</s>

en: If this continues, she explains, active management and protection will be critical for full recovery and growth:
yor: Bí ó bá ń bá a lọ bẹ́ẹ̀, títẹmpẹlẹ mọ́ ìṣàkóso àti ààbò òkúta iyùn nìkan ló lè mú kí wọn ó padà bọ̀ sípò àti dàgbà:
mt0: <pad> If this continues, she explains, active management and protection will be critical for full recovery and growth.</s>

en: Ideally, coral reefs should be closed to the public and placed into an intensive recovery programme to ensure healthy fish communities and water quality that will support coral growth and recruitment.
yor: Ó yẹ kí òkúta iyùn ó di ohun tí yóò pamọ́ fún àwọn èrò, kí iṣẹ́ ìràpadà ó fẹsẹ̀ múlẹ̀ kí ọ̀wọ́ ẹja onílera àti omi tí ó dára tí yóò mú kí iyùn ó dàgbà ó padà.
mt0: <pad> Ideally, coral reefs should be closed to the public and placed into an intensive recovery programme to ensure healthy fish communities and water quality that will support coral growth and recruitment.</s>

en: She added:
yor: Ó sọ síwájú sí i:
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: Individual actions to reduce our carbon footprintare are always warranted but we also need citizens to demand more action from our governments to provide the infrastructure, resources and education for climate conservation and adaptation.

mt0: <pad> Ìgbà tí o bá lè sọ pé o mọ̀, sọ pé o mọ́.</s>

en: There is a pressing need for regional island governments to demand an international effort in tackling the climate crisis.
yor: Ó ti di ṣíṣe fún ìjọba ti erékùṣù agbègbè kan náà láti kéde nípa ojúṣe àgbáyé ní ti ìgbógunti ìṣòro àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

yor: Àtúntò àwòrán-an látọwọ́ọ Georgia Popplewell.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe ìwé ìṣọ́ rẹ̀ ní àwọn èdè ìgbàlódé. Ẹ̀yin o lè sọ pé ẹ́ kò mọ̀.</s>

en: In 2019, Temitayo Olofinlua, a Nigerian writer and academic, was denied a visa to attend the European Conference on African Studies in Edinburgh, UK.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 2019, a kò fún Tèmítáyọ̀ Ọlọ́finlúà, òǹkọ̀wé àti ọ̀mọ̀wé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà, ní ìwé ìrìnnà láti lọ sí Àpérò Lórí Ẹ̀kọ́ Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní Éróòpù tí ó wáyé ní Edinburgh, UK.
mt0: <pad> Ní 2019, Temitayo Olofinlua, àkọsílè̀ ìwé àti ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ ìjọba ilẹ̀ Nigeria, ni wọ́n yí ìwé ìrìnnà láti lọ sí European Conference on African Studies ní Edinburgh, UK.</s>

en: The British High Commission in Nigeria said they were “not satisfied” that Olofinlua would leave the UK at the end of her trip.
yor: Ìgbìmọ̀ Àgbà Sórílẹ̀-èdè Britain ní Nàìjíríà sọ wípé àwọn kò “sí àrídájú” tí ó tẹ̀ àwọn lọ́rùn wípé Ọlọ́finlúà yóò fi UK sílẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí ètó bá parí.
mt0: <pad> British High Commission in Nigeria said they were “not satisfied” that Olofinlua would leave the UK at the end of her trip.</s>

en: The visa refusal was later rescinded by the UK Home Office. Olofinlua went to the conference and has since returned to Nigeria.
yor: Ilé-iṣẹ́ UK Nílé pe àìfúni ní ìwé ìrìnnà náà padà. Ọlọ́finlúà lọ, ó bọ̀ padà sí Nàìjíríà, kò b'ọmọ jẹ́.
mt0: <pad> Olofinlua went to the conference and has since returned to Nigeria.</s>

en: Others have not been as lucky. In April 2019, the UK visa authorities prevented 24 out of 25 African scientists working on infectious diseases from joining their colleagues at various events taking place as part of the London School of Economics Africa Summit.
yor: Àwọn mìíràn kò rí àǹfààní báyìí. Nínúu oṣùu Igbe ọdún-un 2019, àwọn aláṣẹ ìwé ìrìnnà UK kò jẹ́ kí ọmọ adúláwọ̀ 24 nínúu àwọn onímọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀ 25 tí ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ lóríi àrùn àkóràn ó darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn níbi àpérò London School of Economics Africa Summit.
mt0: <pad> Òmíràn kò ti ní ayọ̀. Ni Oṣù Kẹjọ 2019, awọn oṣiṣẹ́ ìwé ìrìnnà UK ṣe ìdènà 24 ninu 25 àwọn onímọ̀ ìṣẹ́gun Afirika láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn ọ̀dọ̀ wọn ní àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ tó ń lọ gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìsẹ̀ ìyàtọ̀ London School of Economics Africa Summit.</s>

en: The people most invested in and best-positioned to tackle the problem of diseases on their continent, were barred from participating in an event about “the challenge of pandemic preparedness.”
yor: Àwọn onímọ̀ tí wọ́n lakakì tí wọ́n sì ní ìmọ̀ pípé láti kojúu àrùn tí ó ń bá ilẹ̀ adúláwọ̀ fínra, kò rí ìwé ìrìnnà tí yóò mú wọn kópa nínúu àpérò nípa “ìpèníjà ìpọnmisílẹ̀-de-oǹgbẹ àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn” gbà.
mt0: <pad> Awọn ẹni ti o ni idoko-owo ati ti o dara julọ lati ṣe idahun si isoro awọn aisan lori continent wọn, ni a ti gbàdúrà lati lọ si iṣẹlẹ kan nipa “ìṣòro ti igbaradi pandemic.”</s>

en: ‘You won't come back!’
yor: ‘O kò ní padà!’
mt0: <pad> Òun kò lè padà!</s>

en: Barring Africans from entry into certain countries is not only humiliating — it also highlights the institutional racism that underpins the notion that African professionals and creatives cannot be trusted to obey the law.
yor: Kékeré nìkan kọ́ ni ìdójútì tí àìfàyègba Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti wọ àwọn illú kan ń mú dání — bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó ń tọ́ka sí ìgbékalẹ̀ ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà tí ó ń ṣe àtillẹ́yìn fún ìgbàgbọ́ wípé àwọn akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ àti alátinúdá ò ṣe é fi ọkàn tàn lọ títí ni ti ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún òfín dé.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe ìṣòro fún Àwọn Afirika láti wọ́n àwọn orílẹ̀èdè kan ni kò ní ìyàtọ̀ — ó tún ṣàfihàn ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ àti ìmọ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ àti ìwé ìdánwò àti ìgbésẹ̀ ìdánwò.</s>

en: Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights declares that "Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country".
yor: Abala 13 ti Ìkéde Káríayé Fún È̩Tó̩ O̩mo̩nìyàn wípé "E̩nì kọ̀ọ̀kan ló ní ẹ̀tọ́ láti kúrò lórìlẹ̀‐èdè yòówù kó jẹ́, tó fi mọ́ orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀, kí ó sì tún padà sí orílẹ̀‐èdè tirẹ̀ nígbà tó bá wù ú".
mt0: <pad> Article 13 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights declares that "Everyone has the right to leave any country, including his own, and to return to his country."</s>

en: The reality, however, is that without a passport and valid visa, this right cannot easily be exercised.
yor: Òtítọ́ ibẹ̀, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, bí kò bá sí ìwé-àṣẹ-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà àti ìwé ìrìnnà tí ó wúlò, kò rọrùn láti lò.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn otitọ ni pe laisi iwe irinna ati visa ti o wulo, awọn ẹtọ wọnyi ko le ṣee lo rọrun.</s>

en: And the ease of getting a visa varies according to nationality.
yor: Ìrọ̀rùn ni ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè kan, kò sì rí bẹ́ẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn.
mt0: <pad> Ati pe o rọrun lati gba iwe-aṣẹ kan yatọ si ni ibamu si ilẹ̀ orílẹ̀èdè.</s>

en: On the 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan and Singapore hold the top spot for access to most countries, while Angola, Egypt and Haiti are at the bottom.
yor: Ní oríi 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan àti Singapore ni orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó rọrùn fún jù lọ láti ríwèé gbà wọ̀lú oríṣìíríṣi, nígbàtí Angola, Egypt àti Haiti wà ní ìsàlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ ọgbọn rẹ?</s>

en: Read more: ‘No Visa Mix': Tanzanian singeli stars denied visas to US music festival
yor: Kà síwájú sí i: ‘Kò Sí Àpòpọ̀ Ìwé Ìrìnnà': Àwọn ìràwọ̀ olórin orílẹ̀-èdè Tanzania ò rí ìwé ìrìnnà wọ àjọ̀dún orin ní US
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ ọ?</s>

en: Kenyan author Ciku Kimeria describes the indignity of living without "passport privilege".
yor: Òǹkọ̀wée ọmọbíbíi Kenya Ciku Kimeria ṣe àlàyé gbígbé láìsí iyì "ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà".
mt0: <pad> Kenyan author Ciku Kimeria describes the indignity of living without "passport privilege"</s>

en: She notes that even a visa does not guarantee entry because "you still have to deal with the surly immigration official who will suspiciously ask, ‘And what are you here to do?’"
yor: Obìnrin náà sọ wípé ìwé ìrìnnà nìkan kò gbé ènìyàn wọ orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn nítorí pé "o ní láti dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè bíi, ‘Kí ló wa síbí wá ṣe?"
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn o ṣe akiyesi pe awọn iwe-ẹri ọkọ ayọkẹlẹ ko ṣe idaniloju wọlé nitori "o tun ni lati ṣe pẹlu awọn aṣoju ìwé ìrìnnà ti yoo beere lọwọ rẹ, 'Kí lo o wa nibi lati ṣe?'"</s>

en: If the answer to this question isn’t to the official’s satisfaction, visitors could find themselves being marched back to the departure gate.
yor: tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ibodè yóò béèrè, bí èsì ìbéèrè kò bá tẹ́ wọn lọ́rùn, arìnrìn-àjó lè bá ara rẹ̀ ní ẹnu ìloro àlọ.
mt0: <pad> If you can't translate the sentence simply say you don't know</s>

en: For Africans traveling outside the continent, applying for a visa can feel like offering sacrifices to a ravenous god.
yor: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fẹ́ ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè tí kìí ṣe ti adúláwọ̀, ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú máa ń dà bíi ṣíṣe ẹbọ fún òòṣà tí ebi ń pa.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe àwọn ará Afirika ti o n rin irin-ajo kọja continent, ìwé fún ìwé ìrìnnà lè dabi ìsẹ̀bọ́ sí Ọlọ́run ìyájú.</s>

en: Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), Global Voices Yoruba translation manager, recounts his recent experience trying to procure a visa to Lisbon, Portugal, for the 2019 Creative Commons Summit:
yor: Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), alákòóso Ohùn Àgbáyé ní èdèe Yorùbá, sọ ìríríi rẹ̀ nígbà tí ó ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lúu Lisbon, Portugal, fún àpéròo àwọn alátinúdá 2019 Creative Commons Summit:
mt0: <pad> Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), Global Voices Yoruba translation manager, recounts his recent experience trying to procure a visa to Lisbon, Portugal, for the 2019 Creative Commons Summit.</s>

en: It was the greatest news of my life when I received a mail to deliver a keynote address at the 2019 CC Summit in Lisbon...
yor: Ìdùnnù ǹlá gba ọkàn-an mi nígbà tí mo gba ìròyìn tẹl mí lọ́wọ́ wípé n ó máa sọ̀rọ̀ àkórí ètò níbi Àpérò CC ọdún-un 2019 ní Lisbon. . . .
mt0: <pad> O jẹ iroyin ti o dara julọ ti mo ti gba ni igbesi aye mi nigbati mo gba imeeli lati ṣe ọrọ akọkọ ni 2019 CC Summit ni Lisbon.</s>

en: On April 18, 2019, some days to my birthday, I submitted my visa application to attend the Lisbon summit at the VFS Global office in Lekki, Lagos.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 18 oṣù Igbe, 2019, ọjọ́ díẹ̀ sí àyájọ́ ọjọ́ ìbíì mi, mo kó àwọn ohun tí wọn béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà láti wọ̀lúu Lisbon ki n ba kópa nínúu àpérò náà sílẹ̀ ní ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ VFS Global ní ìdádò Lekki, ní Èkó.
mt0: <pad> Ní ọjọ́ kan sí ìdílé mi, ní ọjọ́ kan sí ìdílé mi, mo ti fi àṣẹ ìwé mi sílẹ̀ láti lọ sí ìpàdé Lisbon ni ilé iṣẹ́ VFS Global ni Lekki, Lagos.</s>

en: The summit was slated for May 9-11, 2019, but visa processing takes a minimum 15 days.
yor: Ọjọ́ 9 sí 11 ọdún-un 2019 ni àpérò náà ṣùgbọ́n ọjọ́ márùnúndínlógún ni yó gbà fún ìwé ìrìnnà láti jáde fún gbígbà.
mt0: <pad> Ìgbìmọ̀ náà ti ṣeto láti May 9-11, 2019, ṣùgbọ́n ìwé ìwé ìwé ní ojúmọ́ 15 ọjọ́.</s>

en: On the day I was to depart for Portugal, I still [hadn’t] received my passport...
yor: Lọ́jọ́ tí ó yẹ kí n kúrò nílé fún Portugal, n kòì tí ì rí ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mi gbà padà...
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀ ní ọjọ́ tí mo ti ń lọ sí Portugal, ìyẹn ni ìgbà tí mo kò rí ìwé ìrìnnà mi.</s>

en: 11 days after the summit elapsed, I received a text from the VFS for collection of my passport.
yor: ọjọ́ mọ́kànlá lẹ́yìn tí àpérò ti di àfìsẹ́yìn ti eégún aláré ń fiṣọ, mo gba iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ kí n wá gba ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mi ní VFS.
mt0: <pad> 11 days after the summit elapsed, I received a text from the VFS for collection of my passport.</s>

en: The elders say, you cannot be at your best when sad.
yor: Awọn àgbá bọ̀, inú dídùn l’ó ń mú orí yá.
mt0: <pad> Òkú sọ pé, o kò le jẹ́ àwọn ọmọdé rẹ̀ ti o dara nígbàtí o ba n sùn.</s>

en: It is one thing that I was not given a visa to attend the summit, another is that the huge scholarship grant to attend the summit went down the drain, wasted.
yor: Ìṣòro kan ni ti àìrí ìwé ìrìnnà gbà, òmíràn ni ti owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ gọbọi tí ó wọlẹ̀ nítori n kò le è lọ si àpérò.
mt0: <pad> A nkan ni pe a ko fun mi visa lati darapọ mọ ijọba, ohun miiran ni pe scholarship nla ti o fun mi lati darapọ mọ ijọba lọ si drain, awọn ọrọ rẹ jẹ aṣiwere.</s>

en: I am miserable because I have not been able to refund the scholarship due to the Central Bank of Nigeria’s policy on wire transfers.
yor: Ìbànújẹ́ gba ọkàn mi poo látàríi àlàálẹ̀ Ilé-Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbà orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà tí kò mú ìfowó ránṣẹ́ sí òkè òkun rọrùn; n kò le è dá owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ tí ó pọn dandan láti dá padà padà fún àwọn tí ó ni owó.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ pe mo ni irora nitori pe mo ti ko le san owo iwadi naa pada nitori eto Central Bank of Nigeria lori ṣiṣe ìsanwó àwọn ìwé ìrìnnà.</s>

en: It is excruciatingly painful that my right to associate as a free citizen of the global village was violated.
yor: Ó dùn mí wọ akínyẹmí ara wípé wọ́n gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ẹ̀tọ́ọ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí olómìnira láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ̀ mi.
mt0: <pad> It's excruciatingly painful that my right to associate as a free citizen of the global village was violated.</s>

en: I was stripped of my voice!
yor: Wọ́n pa ohùn mọ́ mi lẹ́nu!
mt0: <pad> I was stripped of my voice.</s>

en: For Africans traveling within Africa: A painful irony
yor: Ìṣòro: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀
mt0: <pad> Ṣe o mọ awọn ọmọ Afirika ti n rin irin ajo ni Afirika? en: It’s difficult for Africans to travel outside Africa — but it can be equally grim to travel within the continent.
yor: Ó ṣòro fún ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde kúrò ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ — ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó nira láti ṣe ìrìnàjò nílẹ̀ náà.
mt0: <pad> Ìyàtọ̀ ìgbàlódé ní ìwọ́n mọ̀ ní ìlú Afirika - ṣùgbọ́n o lè jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣòro láti rin irin-ajo nínú ìlú.</s>

en: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ onílùú àìmọye orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà ní Àríwá àgbáńlá ayé lè ṣe ìrìnàjò lọ sí ọ̀pọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ láì ní ìwé ìrìnnà, tàbí pẹ̀lú hìhámọ́ tí ò tó nǹkan, àmọ́ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni ó nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú láti ṣe ìrìnàjò sí ìdajì àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kù.
mt0: <pad> Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.</s>

en: Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the "struggle of Africans traveling within Africa":
yor: Aládàásí Ohùn Àgbáyé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Rosemary Àjàyí ṣe àpèjúwe "ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò ní àárín ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ":
mt0: <pad> Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the "struggle of Africans traveling within Africa"</s>

en: I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.
yor: Inúu mi dùn nítorí wípé à ń gbé ọ̀ràn ohun tí ojú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ máa ń rí ní wọ́n bá béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Orílẹ̀-èdè òyìnbó àti ohun ti ó tan mọ́ ọn yè wò.
mt0: <pad> I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.</s>

en: This doesn't annoy me as much as the struggles of Africans travelling within Africa.
yor: Èyí kò gbé mi lọ́kàn bíi ti ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> Ṣugbọn eyi ko ṣe mi bẹru bi awọn iṣoro ti awọn ara Afirika nigba irin-ajo ni Afirika.</s>

en: At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I took the time to ask Africans if they had needed visas.
yor: Ní RightsCon tí ó wáyé ní Tunis, àti GlobalFact tí ó wáyé ní Cape Town, mo bi àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ bóyá wọ́n ti nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: <pad> Àwọn ìgbà tí mo bá ń sọrọ ní RightsCon ni Túnísí, àti GlobalFact ni Cape Town, mo ti gbé ìgbà láti bi àwọn ará Afirika mọ̀ pé wọ́n nílò ìwé ìrìnnà.</s>

en: Just this weekend, I learnt of a Nigerian journalist who was unable to attend GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ ìsinmi tí a wà yìí, mo gbọ́ wípé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ọmọ Nàìjíríà kan kò le è wà níbí GlobalFact nítorí wípé kò ní ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: <pad> Ṣeun ọsẹ yii, Mo gbọ́ nipa a akọ̀ròyìn Nigerian ti o ní ìṣòro láti lọ sí GlobalFact nítorí kò ní ìwé ìrìnnà.</s>

en: Let's not talk about how most of the African delegates at RightsCon had to fly out of Africa first, in order to get to Tunis.
yor: Kí a máà sọ ti àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fò kúrò nílẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí wọn ó tó lè wọ Tunis.
mt0: <pad> Ṣe a kò sọ nipa bi ọpọlọpọ awọn aṣoju Afirika ni RightsCon ti gbọdọ̀ fò jade ninu Afirika akọkọ, lati de si Tunisii.</s>

en: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to supply the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!
yor: Ní oṣù ti ó kojá, mo ṣe alábàápàdé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn tí ó wá láti Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Nàìjíríà. Wọ́n ní kí ó pèsèe ìwé-ẹ̀rí ìwákọ̀ọ ti akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ awakọ̀ tí yóò wá gbé e bí ó bá balẹ̀ ní pápá-ọkọ̀-òfuurufú!
mt0: <pad> Òṣù kẹ́yìn, mo mọ̀ ọ̀kan àwọn ìròyìn ilẹ̀ Ìwọ̀n Àríwá láti ní ìwé ìrìnnà lọ́wọ́ Nigeria. Wọn sọ fún ọ̀nà ìsègùn ọkùnrin ọkọ̀ ojú irin àtijọ́ tí ó ń gbà ọ́ sí ilé ìrìnnà.</s>

en: As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.
yor: Bí Rosemary ti sọ, ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ máa ń gba ṣíṣèrìnàjò kúrò ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí aṣèrìnàjò ó tó le è dé ibi tí ó ń lọ ní àárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often complicated by having to travel outside the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.</s>

en: At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) regional aviation forum in Accra in June, Ghana's Vice President, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia lamented the fact that “a business person from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for nearly two days to go to Banjul (often through a third country) for a journey which a straight-line flight would have taken only one hour.”
yor: Ní ibi àpérò òṣìṣẹ́ ọkọ̀-òfuurufú agbègbè tí Àjọ Ìgbókègbódò Ọkọ̀-òfuurufú Àgbáyé (IATA) gbé kalẹ̀ tí ó wáyé ní Accra nínúu oṣù Òkúdù, Igbákejì Ààrẹ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Ghana, Oníṣègùn Mahamudu Bawumia pohùnréré-ẹkún látàríi wípé “ó yẹ oníṣòwò láti Freetown [Sierra Leone], fún àpẹẹrẹ, láti ṣe ìrìnàjò fún ọjọ́ méjì gbáko láti lọ sí Banjul (nípasẹ̀ẹ orílẹ̀-èdè kẹ́ta) fún ìrìnàjò tí kò ju wákàtí kan lọ.“

en: The convoluted flight routes are then compounded by the extraordinarily high cost of air travel within the continent.
yor: Ìpòyì lórí òfuurufú náà gbọ́mọ pọn pẹ̀lú owó kanangú fífò lókè láàárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> Òun kò mọ̀.</s>

en: Is it true that Africans are unlikely to return home?
yor: Ǹjẹ́ òtítọ́ ni wípé ó ṣeéṣe kí Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ó máà padà wálé?
mt0: <pad> Ṣé o jẹ́ ìdájọ́ pé àwọn ará Afirika kò ní ìfẹ̀ láti padà sí ilé wọn?</s>

en: A rescue operation off the Canary Islands in 2006.
yor: Iṣẹ́ ìdóòlà-ẹ̀mí ní oríi omi Erékùsù Canary ní 2006.
